bookCover.coverDescription: An Interactive book on vertebrates for grade 5 students.

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text: We see a variety of animals in our surroundings like butterfly, frog, snake, lizard, grasshopper, snail, fish, bird, cow, rat, etc. Among them, frog, snake, lizard, bird, cow, fish and rat have backbones or vertebral columns. These animals are called vertebrates. So, vertebrates can be defined as the animals having a backbone or vertebral column. These animals have endoskeleton which forms the internal framework of the body. The characteristics of vertebrates are given below:

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text:
• They have a backbone or vertebral column.

  • They have bones in their bodies.

  • They may be cold-blooded or warm-blooded.

  • They have a well-developed blood circulatory system.

  • They have a well developed nervous system which consists of brain and spinal cord.

  • They move with the help of fins, limbs or wings.

params.question: The animal shown above is a vertebrate animal.

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text:
• Class Pisces

Different types of fishes are grouped in Class Pisces. Fishes are cold-blooded aquatic vertebrates having fins and gills. They cannot live on land. Some fishes are very small and some are very big.

Characteristics:

  • The body of fishes can be divided into head, trunk and tail.
  • They breathe through gills in water.
  • They move with the help of fins.
  • They are cold-blooded animals.
  • Their body is covered with smooth, slippery and water-proof scales.
  • They lay eggs in water.

Examples: Rohu, Sea horse, Carp, Shark, etc.

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text:
• Class Amphibia

Different types of frogs, toads and salamanders are kept in Class Amphibia. These animals can live in water as well as on land. The vertebrates that can live on land and in water are called amphibians. They spend some part of life in water and rest on land.

Characteristics:

  • The body of amphibians can be divided into head and trunk.
  • Their body is covered with smooth or rough skin.
  • Their skin is rich in glands.
  • They breathe through skin in water and through lungs on land.
  • They move with the help of limbs.
  • They are cold-blooded animals.
  • They lay eggs in water.

Examples: Frog, Toad, Salamander, etc.

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text:
• Class Reptilia

Different types of snakes, lizards and crocodiles are grouped in class Reptilia. These animals crawl on ground. So, reptiles are crawling cold-blooded vertebrates. Most of them live on land but some live in water. Reptiles are also called creepers or crawlers.

Characteristics:

  • Reptiles creep or crawl on land.
  • Their body can be divided into head, neck, trunk and tail.
  • Their body is covered with hard and dry scales.
  • They move with the help of limbs but limbs are absent in snakes.
  • They breathe through lungs.
  • They lay eggs. The eggs have leathery shells.

Examples: Snake, Lizard, Tortoise, Crocodile, etc.

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text:
• Class Aves

Different types of birds are kept in Class Aves. Birds are the vertebrates that can fly in air. They are found on land and in air.

Characteristics:

  • Birds have feathers and wings.
  • Their body can be divided into head, neck, trunk and tail.
  • They have very light bones and toothless beak.
  • They breathe through lungs.
  • They are warm-blooded animals.
  • They lay eggs.

Examples: Crow, Eagle, Hen, Penguin, Duck, etc.

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text:
• Class Mammalia

Different types of vertebrates having mammary glands are grouped in Class Mammalia. Mammals are warm-blooded vertebrates that directly give birth to their young ones and suckle them. Most mammals live on land but some live in water.

Characteristics:

  • Mammals directly give birth to their young ones and suckle them.
  • Mammary glands or milk producing glands are present.
  • Their body remains covered with hair.
  • They have a pair of external ears.
  • Their body can be divided into head, neck, trunk and tail.
  • They breathe through lungs.
  • They are warm-blooded animals.
  • They move with the help of fins, limbs or wings.

Examples: Cow, Tiger, Dolphin, Dog, Cat, Zebra, etc.

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.textField:
1) Amphibians do not have *neck*.
2) Cow belongs to class *Mammalia*.
3) *Reptiles* are crawling cold-blooded vertebrates.
4) Shark belongs to class *Pisces*.
5) *Snake* is a cold-blooded animal.
6) Birds have *wings* for flying.
